basics.name: Sean Beach
basics.label: Software Engineer
basics.summary: Sean is a software engineer, specializing in Android app development, with a passion for video games and coffee. Sean started his software career at Auburn University, where he learned the basics of programming. The following year, he transferred to the University of Memphis to complete his Computer Science education. After graduation, he moved from Memphis to Nashville upon accepting an offer to work as an Android developer. Sean likes to spend his free time watching movies with his wife, playing video games, improving his skills, and reading about the technology industry at large. After moving to Nashville, he developed an interest in specialty coffee, and enjoys trying different coffees from around the world. His favorite games are of the Fire Emblem series, which are turn based tactics games, and 4X games such as Endless Legend and the Civilization series.

work.summary: Working as part of distributed teams and directly with customers to delight and develop amazing software. Primary focus on Android development, with minor personal experience in iOS. Short tenure on Angular project, using Cordova and the Ionic framework to develop apps for both Android and iOS from one code base.

Developed and maintained an Android application platform for reading and annotating ePub content. ePubs are streamed over the internet via an internal API, or downloaded and parsed locally. All content is encrypted at time of download, and decrypted on the fly as the user reads, including HTML5 video content. The platform also included a verbose library screen for all of the user's owned content, and an in-app store where they can purchase more. This project, via Gradle flavors and flexible coding, became the basis for 5 published applications on the Google Play store, the most prominent being WORDsearch Bible (https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.lifeway.wordsearchreader) with over 20,000 unique users and over 30,000 total installations.

Android development as part of a faculty research project with Dr. Timothy Hnat. Attempted to modify the Android Open Source Project to include a new OS-level security protocol. The goal was to implement behavior learning of user action. Based upon past usage, the protocol would be able to recognize the device owner based upon hardware sensor readings, and determine if the current user is the owner. If the protocol detected otherwise, other security mechanisms would take effect, such as confirmation of device password, or answering a security question.
Created spreadsheets and used proprietary software to manage inventory of returned products in a supply chain warehouse. Communicated directly to the customers to resolve any outstanding issues.

volunteer.summary: Helping organize monthly meetings for mobile technology professionals to network and increase their technical proficiencies. Past content has included Android study groups, iOS and Swift tutorials, and getting started with Unity. The group is a Google Development Group, and hosts an official Google I/O Extended event. Learn more about this group at Meetup.com. https://www.meetup.com/NashvilleMDUG/

Working with a group of volunteer technology professionals to create a classroom lesson for high school juniors and seniors to interest them in technology and show them the awesome things that can be done through code. Read more about this project and watch the related video at medium.com. https://medium.com/hack-tennessee/hacking-with-purpose-30ac34313b87

awards.title: Developing Android Apps
awards.summary: Certification of completion for online course. https://www.udacity.com/course/ud853
